context: 25 Higher malondialdehyde levels has been observed in the serum of women exposed to high levels of particulate matter related to burning biomass fuel. 26 Malondialdehyde in the plasma of cement plant workers was negatively correlated with FEV1 and erythrocyte reduced glutathione. 4 High levels of malondialdehyde have also been observed in the EBC of workers exposed to cobalt and tungsten. 6 Diesel-exposed toll collectors have been reported to have significantly higher plasma malondialdehyde and nitrite+nitrate levels than office workers, suggesting that malondialdehyde and nitrite+nitrate levels may be used as biological markers of oxidative stress related to diesel exhaust exposure. 5 Although malondialdehyde is not a specific product of lipid peroxidation and the reliability of using malondialdehyde as a marker of oxidative stress in vivo has been questioned, 27 with the advent of sensitive techniques measuring malondialdehyde with HPLC separation and fluorescence detection, 7,9,28,29 such as used in the current study, reliable data have been obtained. Although malondialdehyde represents only approximately 1% of lipid peroxides, it can be used as a marker of oxidative stress in clinical settings. 7,26,29 A recent study comparing children with asthma and control children reported detectable levels of malondialdehyde and erythrocyte reduced glutathione in exhaled breath in the children with asthma that increased during asthma exacerbation.
